The '''International Wages for Housework Campaign''' was a feminist global social movement, which grew out of the International Feminist Collective in [[Italy]] in 1972 and organized resistance and public debate on the social formations produced by gendered labor and [[reproductive labor]], for example domestic work like [[Homemaking|housework]], [[childcare]], [[gender discrimination]], and the socially reinforced performance of [[gender roles]], gendered desire, and leisure inequality. The Campaign's platform included the women's right to work outside of the home, [[Unemployment benefits in Italy|unemployment benefits]], parental leave, and equal pay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.generation-online.org/p/fpdallacosta1.htm|title=The door to the garden|last=www.generation-online.org|first=Mariarosa Dalla Costa + EE + AB|website=www.generation-online.org|access-date=2016-12-06}}</ref><ref name="nplusonemag.com" /> The Campaign was formed in [[Padua]], Italy by [[Selma James]], [[Brigitte Galtier]], [[Mariarosa Dalla Costa]], and [[Silvia Federici]]. A major tenet of the campaign was that reproductive labor is the foundation of industrial work, in its important role in the maintenance and care of gendered male workers, yet a type of labor not recognized as productive enough to be [[wage labor]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=James|first=Selma|title=Is Transformation Possible? They Say We Can't. We Must|jstor=20838923|journal=Off Our Backs|volume=38|issue=1|page=42|year=2008}}</ref>
The demands for the Wages for Housework used [[Marxist]] frameworks to think through the reliance of capitalist economies on exploitative labor practices against certain populations.<ref name="nplusonemag.com">[http://nplusonemag.com/more-smiles-more-money "More Smiles, More Money." N+1 Magazine. August 2013]</ref> [[Mariarosa Dalla Costa]] and some participants in the Wages for Housework campaign were enmeshed in the intellectual movement ''[[operaismo]],'' which developed around factory strikes in [[Northern Italy]] in the 1970s. The Wages for Housework Campaign shared with ''operaismo'' the idea that the fair working conditions including wage is key to the social recognition of labor. ''Operaismo'' encouraged workers to act in their direct interests, and engage in factory strikes to demand better conditions. The Wages for Housework campaign applied also shared discussions about the [[social factory]] with [[operaismo]]; whereby "the whole of society lives as a function of the factory and the factory extends its exclusive domination to the whole of society".<ref name="F&S">{{cite web|last1=Tronti|first1=Mario|title=Factory and Society|url=https://operaismoinenglish.wordpress.com/2013/06/13/factory-and-society/|website=Operaismo in English|accessdate=6 May 2017|date=1962}}</ref> The campaign activities included student protests, community workshops, and direct action protest.
Wages for Housework published a [[autonomist Marxism|Marxist autonomist]] journal, ''Matériaux pour l’intervention.'' Several publications grew out of its ideas, which expanded on the claims of the original group and of more general topics in labor and exploitation. In Italy, ''Quaderni rossi,'' published by [[Raniero Panzieri]], and [[Mario Tronti]], dealt with a variety of topics relating to the class struggle.
==United States== In 1973, [[Silvia Federici]] helped start Wages for Housework groups in the US and in 1975, the Wages for Housework opened an office in [[Brooklyn]], New York at 288 B. 8th St. The New York group was called the "Wages for Housework Committee."<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://www.metamute.org/editorial/articles/permanent-reproductive-crisis-interview-silvia-federici|title = Permanent Reproductive Crisis: An Interview with Silvia Federici|date = March 2013|accessdate = |website = Meta Mute|publisher = Mute|last = Vishmidt|first = Marina}}</ref> [http://bcrw.barnard.edu/archive/sexualhealth/WagesForHousework.pdf Flyers] handed out in support of the New York Wages for Housework Committee [http://bcrw.barnard.edu/archive/workforce/Wages_for_Housework.pdf called for all women] to join regardless of marital status, nationality, sexual orientation, number of children, or employment.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://bcrw.barnard.edu/archive/workforce/Wages_for_Housework.pdf|title = The Campaign for Wages for Housework|date = 1975|accessdate = 22 October 2015|website = bcrw.barnard.edu|publisher = Barnard Center for Research on Women|last = |first = }}</ref> In 1975 Federici published ''Wages Against Housework,'' the book most commonly associated with the movement.<ref name=":2" />
Branches of the Wages for Housework Committee appeared in other cities across America. They were organized in [[Boston]], [[Los Angeles]], [[San Francisco]], [[Chicago]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Tulsa]], and [[Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Poor Workers' Union: Rebuilding Labor from Below|last = Tait|first = Vanessa|publisher = South End Press|year = 2005|isbn = 978-0896087149|location = Boston|pages = 38}}</ref> Along with these committees, other autonomous organizations that fall within the Wages for Housework campaign began to organize within the United States.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://freedomarchives.org/Documents/Finder/DOC500_scans/500.020.Wages.for.Housework.pdf|title = The International Wages for Housework Campaign|date = |accessdate = 10 October 2015|website = Freedomarchives.org|publisher = The Freedom Archives|last = |first = }}</ref> For example, in 1974 International Black Women for Wages for Housework was founded by Margaret Prescod and Wilmette Brown in New York City. Prescod also founded the Black Women for Wages for Housework in Los Angeles alongside Sidney Ross-Risden in 1980. The Black Women for Wages for Housework focused on not only unpaid housework for the average housewife, but specific issues of black and third world women. They called for reparations for "slavery, imperialism and neo-colonialism."<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1987-05-07/news/vw-4294_1_unremunerated-work|title = Waging the War Over Wages: Fight for Homemaker Pay has Seen Ups, Downs|date = May 1987|accessdate = 6 November 2015|website = latimes|publisher = Los Angeles Times|last = Hendrix|first = Kathleen}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Feminists Who Changed America, 1963-1975|last = Love|first = Barbara|publisher = University of Illinois Press|year = 2006|isbn = 978-0252031892|location = Chicago|pages = 368}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1985-07-28/news/vw-5698_1_unpaid-work|title = Campaign Catches On: L.A. Pair Seek Wages for Women's Unpaid Work|last = Hendrix|first = Kathleen|date = July 28, 1985|work = Newspaper|access-date = 22 October 2015|via = Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
Both San Francisco and Philadelphia were home to Wages Due Lesbians, an organization that was first created in Britain in 1975. Wages Due Lesbians called for wages for housework along with extra wages for lesbians for "the additional physical and emotional housework of surviving in a hostile and prejudiced society, recognized as work and paid for so all women have the economic power to afford sexual choices."<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" /> Wages Due Lesbians also worked alongside The Lesbian Mothers' National Defense Fund, founded in 1974 and based in Seattle, which aimed to help lesbian mothers who were a part of custody cases after coming out.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.outhistory.org/exhibits/show/lmndf/lmndf|title = The Lesbian Mothers National Defense Fund, the 1970s through 1990s|date = |accessdate = 6 November 2015|website = outhistory.org|publisher = Out History|last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = The A to Z of the Lesbian Liberation Movement: Still the Rage|last = Myers|first = JoAnne|publisher = Scarecrow Press|year = 2009|isbn = 978-0810863279|location = Plymouth|pages = xxxvi}}</ref>
San Francisco was also home to the U.S. PROStitutes Collective (US PROS). US PROS was created in 1982 to help decriminalize prostitution and also prevent men, women, and children from being forced into prostitution.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = US PROS Collective|url = http://uspros.net/|website = US PROS Collective|accessdate = 2015-10-23|language = en-US}}</ref> Likewise, Tulsa housed the No Bad Women, Just Bad Laws Coalitions. It was founded by Ruth Taylor Todasco in 1981 and also focused on the decriminalization of sex work.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Feminists Who Changed America, 1963-1965|last = Love|first = Barbara|publisher = University of Illinois Press|year = 2006|isbn = 978-0252031892|location = Chicago|pages = 463}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://hivandthelaw.com/sites/default/files/null/Overs_SexworkerRights.pdf|title = 'No Bad Women, Just Bad Laws': Three Decades of Sex Work Law Reform Advocacy|date = 2012|accessdate = 22 October 2015|website = HIV and the Law|publisher = Criminalize Hate Not HIV|last = Overs|first = Cheryl}}</ref>
==Social wage campaigns== Wages for Housework is part of more general [[social wage]] campaigns in the 1970s interested in [[late capitalism]]. These campaigns used analysis of [[Fordist]] compromises during the twentieth century to argue that [[family wages]] or social security payments had amounted to wages paid for housework in the advanced capitalist West.<ref name=Himmelweit>{{cite journal|last=Himmelweit|first=Susan F | last2 = Mohun | first2 = Simon | author-link1 = Susan Himmelweit | title = Domestic labour and capital |journal= Cambridge Journal of Economics |date=1977 |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages= 15–31 |url =http://cje.oxfordjournals.org/content/1/1/15.full.pdf+html }}</ref><ref>[http://www.newint.org/features/1988/03/05/wages/ Zoë Fairbairns, "Wages For Housework", ''New Internationalist'', issue 181, March 1988.]</ref> A number of other autonomous organizations interested in compensation for domestic labor were formed in 1975: Black Women for Wages for Housework, Wages Due Lesbians, the [[English Collective of Prostitutes]] (ECP) and some years later WinVisible (women with visible and invisible disabilities).
==Recent history== In recent years,{{When|date=June 2015}} the demands of the Wages for Housework Campaign have been applied to many more recent debates in the gendered aspects of labor including, reproductive rights, sex work, and demands for women in leadership roles in business.<ref name="nplusonemag.com"/>
Silvia Federici and several others from the early campaign have continued to publish books and articles related to the demands of Wages for Housework including Fererici's 2012 book, ''Revolution at Point Zero: Housework, Reproduction, and Feminist Struggle.''

''[https://monoskop.org/images/2/23/Federici_Silvia_Wages_Against_Housework_1975.pdf Wages Against Housework]''. Published jointly by the Power of Women Collective and the Falling Wall Press, 1975. {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Subspeciesbox | name = Western lowland gorilla | status = CR | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iucnredlist.org/species/9406/102328866|title=The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species|website=IUCN Red List of Threatened Species|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref> | image = WesternLowlandGorilla03.jpg | image_caption = Male silverback | image2 = WesternLowlandGorilla05.jpg | image2_caption = Female and juvenile at the [[Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden|Cincinnati Zoo]] | genus = Gorilla | species = gorilla | species_link = Western gorilla | subspecies = gorilla | authority = ([[Savage (biologist)|Savage]], 1847) | range_map = Distibución gorilla.png | range_map_caption = Distribution range in red }} The '''western lowland gorilla''' (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') is one of two subspecies of the [[western gorilla]] (''Gorilla gorilla'') that lives in [[montane forest|montane]], [[primary forest|primary]] and [[secondary forest]]s and lowland swamps in central Africa in [[Angola]], [[Cameroon]], [[Central African Republic]], [[Republic of the Congo]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Equatorial Guinea]] and [[Gabon]]. It is the [[nominate subspecies]] of the western gorilla, and smallest of the four [[gorilla]] subspecies.
The Western lowland gorilla is the only subspecies kept in zoos with the exception of Amahoro, a female [[Eastern lowland gorilla]] at [[Antwerp Zoo]] and a few [[Mountain gorilla]]s kept captive in [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]].<ref name="Prince-Hughes66">{{cite book |title= Songs of the Gorilla Nation|last= Prince-Hughes|first= Dawn|authorlink= Dawn Prince-Hughes|year= 1987|publisher= Harmony|location= |isbn=1-4000-5058-8|page= 66}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Gorilla Male Global.jpg|thumb|left|Skull of a male subject]] The western lowland gorilla is the smallest subspecies of gorilla but nevertheless still a primate of exceptional size and strength. This species of gorillas exhibits pronounced [[sexual dimorphism]]. They possess no tails and have jet black skin along with coarse black hair that covers their entire body except for the face, ears, hands and feet. The hair on the back and rump of males takes on a grey coloration and is also lost as they get progressively older. This coloration is the reason why older males are known as "silverbacks". Their hands are proportionately large with nails on all digits, similar to that of a human's, and very large thumbs. They have short muzzles, a prominent brow ridge, large nostrils and small eyes and ears. Other features are large muscles in the jaw region along with broad and strong teeth. Among these teeth are strong sets of frontal canines and large molars in the back of the mouth for grinding fruits<ref name="Remis1997">{{cite journal|last1=Remis|first1=Melissa J.|title=Western lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') as seasonal frugivores: Use of variable resources|journal=American Journal of Primatology|volume=43|issue=2|year=1997|pages=87–109|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1098-2345(1997)43:2<87::AID-AJP1>3.0.CO;2-T|pmid=9327094}}</ref> and vegetables.<ref name="Csomos">{{cite web|last=Csomos|first=Rebecca Ann|title=Gorilla gorilla western gorilla|url=http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/accounts/Gorilla_gorilla/#lifespan_longevity|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref>
A male standing erect can be up to {{convert|1.8|m|abbr=on|-1}} tall and weigh up to {{convert|270|kg|abbr=on|-1}}.<ref name=Philadelphia>{{cite web |url=http://www.philadelphiazoo.org/zoo/Meet-Our-Animals/Mammals/Primates/Western-Lowland-Gorilla.htm |title=Western lowland gorilla |publisher=[[Philadelphia Zoo]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> Males have an average weight of {{convert|140|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, females of {{convert|90|kg|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Williamson|first1=E.A.|last2=Butynski|first2=T.M.|year=2009|chapter=Gorilla gorilla|editor=Butynski, T.M.|title=The Mammals of Africa|volume=6|publisher=Elsevier Press}}</ref> Males in captivity, however, are noted to be capable of reaching weights up to {{convert|275|kg|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Csomos"/> Males stand upright at {{convert|163|cm|in|abbr=on}}, females at {{convert|1.5|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Philadelphia/> According to the late [[John Aspinall (zoo owner)|John Aspinall]] a silverback gorilla in his prime has the physical strength of seven or eight Olympic weightlifters, but this claim is unverified. Western gorillas frequently stand upright, but walk in a hunched, quadrupedal fashion, with hands curled and knuckles touching the ground. This style of movement requires long arms, which works for western gorillas because the arm span of gorillas is larger than their standing height.
===Albinism=== [[File:Snowflake - Barcelona Zoo White Gorilla3.jpg|thumb|[[Snowflake (gorilla)|Snowflake]], in the [[Barcelona Zoo]]]] The only known [[albinism|albino]] gorilla – named [[Snowflake (gorilla)|Snowflake]] – was a wild-born western lowland gorilla originally from [[Equatorial Guinea]]. Snowflake, a male gorilla, was taken from the wild and brought to the [[Barcelona Zoo]] in 1966 at a very young age. Snowflake presented the typical traits and characteristics of albinism typically seen in humans, including white hair, pinkish skin, light colored eyes, reduced [[visual perception]] and [[photophobia]] (discomfort in bright light). Snowflake was diagnosed by scientists as having non-syndromic albinism. The genetic variant for Snowflake’s albinism was identified by the scientists as a non-synonymous [[single nucleotide polymorphism]] located in a [[transmembrane region]] of [[SLC45A2]]. This transporter is also known to be involved in [[oculocutaneous albinism type 4]] in humans. This information revealed the first evidence of [[inbreeding]] in western lowland gorillas.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Prado-Martinez|first=Javier|last2=Hernando-Herraez|first2=Irene|last3=Lorente-Galdos|first3=Belen|last4=Dabad|first4=Marc|last5=Ramirez|first5=Oscar|last6=Baeza-Delgado|first6=Carlos|last7=Morcillo-Suarez|first7=Carlos|last8=Alkan|first8=Can|last9=Hormozdiari|first9=Fereydoun|date=14 January 2013|title=The genome sequencing of an albino Western lowland gorilla reveals inbreeding in the wild|journal=BMC Genomics|volume=14|issue=363|pages=363|doi=10.1186/1471-2164-14-363|pmc=3673836|pmid=23721540|last10=Raineri|first10=Emanuele|last11=Estellé|first11=Jordi|last12=Fernandez-Callejo|first12=Marcos|last13=Valles|first13=Mònica|last14=Ritscher|first14=Lars|last15=Schöneberg|first15=Torsten|last16=de la Calle-Mustienes|first16=Elisa|last17=Casillas|first17=Sònia|last18=Rubio-Acero|first18=Raquel|last19=Melé|first19=Marta|last20=Engelken|first20=Johannes|last21=Caceres|first21=Mario|last22=Gomez-Skarmeta|first22=Jose|last23=Gut|first23=Marta|last24=Bertranpetit|first24=Jaume|last25=Gut|first25=Ivo G|last26=Abello|first26=Teresa|last27=Eichler|first27=Evan E|last28=Mingarro|first28=Ismael|last29=Lalueza-Fox|first29=Carles|last30=Navarro|first30=Arcadi|display-authors=29}}</ref>
==Behavior==
===Social structure=== [[File:Westernlowlandgorilla-ueno2009.ogv|thumb|left|250px|Western lowland gorillas at a [[Ueno Zoo]] in [[Tokyo]], Japan]]
Western lowland gorilla groups travel within a home range averaging {{convert|8|-|45|sqkm|abbr=on|}}. Gorillas do not display territorial behavior, and neighboring groups often overlap ranges.<ref name="Bermejo2004">{{cite journal|last1=Bermejo|first1=M.|title=Home-range use and intergroup encounters in western gorillas (Gorilla g. gorilla) at Lossi forest, North Congo|journal=American Journal of Primatology|volume=64|issue=2|year=2004|pages=223–232|doi=10.1002/ajp.20073|pmid=15470740|url=http://www.eva.mpg.de/primat/ebola_workshop/pdf/Bermejo_gorilla_ranging.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name="Doran-SheehyGreer2004">{{cite journal|last1=Doran-Sheehy|first1=Diane M.|last2=Greer|first2=David|last3=Mongo|first3=Patrice|last4=Schwindt|first4=Dylan|title=Impact of ecological and social factors on ranging in western gorillas|journal=American Journal of Primatology|volume=64|issue=2|year=2004|pages=207–222|doi=10.1002/ajp.20075|pmid=15470743|url=http://www.eva.mpg.de/primat/ebola_workshop/pdf/Doran_mondika_ranging_paper.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> The group usually favours a certain area within the home range but seems to follow a seasonal pattern depending upon the availability of ripening fruits and, at some sites, localised large open clearings (swamps and "bais"). Gorillas normally travel {{convert|3|-|5|km|abbr=on}} per day. Populations feeding on high-energy foods that vary spatially and seasonally tend to have greater day ranges than those feeding on lower-quality but more consistently available foods. Larger groups travel greater distances in order to obtain sufficient food.<ref name="Remis1997"/>
It was found that it is easier for males to travel alone and move between groups as a result of the solidarity they experienced before finding their own breeding group. Before reaching the age of sexual maturity, males leave their natal group and go through a “bachelor stage” that can last several years either in solitary or in a nonbreeding group.<ref name=Douadi>{{cite journal|last=Douadi|first=Melanie|title=Sex-biased dispersal in western lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'')|journal=Molecular Ecology|date=June 2007|volume=16|issue=11|pages=2247–2259|pmid=17561888|last2=Gatti|first2=S|last3=Levrero|first3=F|last4=Duhamel|first4=G|last5=Bermejo|first5=M|last6=Vallet|first6=D|last7=Menard|first7=N|last8=Petit|first8=E. J.|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2007.03286.x}}</ref> However, while both sexes leave their birth group, females are never found alone; they just travel from breeding group to breeding group. It was also found that males like to settle with other male members of their family. Their breeding groups consist of one silverback male, three adult females and their offspring.<ref name=Douadi/> The male gorilla takes on the role of the protector. Females tend to make bonds with other females in their natal group only, but rather form strong bonds with males. Males also compete aggressively with each other for contact with females.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Maestripieri, Dario |author2=Ross, Stephen |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Sex differences in play among western lowland gorilla (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') infants: Implications for adult behavior and social structure|journal= American Journal of Physical Anthropology|volume= 123|issue=1 |year=2004|pages= 52–61|doi=10.1002/ajpa.10295|pmid=14669236}}</ref>
The group of gorillas is led by one or more adult males. In cases where there are more than one silverback males in a group, they are most likely father and son. Groups containing only one male are believed to be the basic unit of the social group, gradually growing in size due to reproduction and new members migrating in. In the study done at Lope, gorillas harvest most of their food arboreally, but less than half of their night nests are built in trees.<ref>Tutin, Caroline. "Ranging and social structure of lowland gorillas in the Lope Reserv, Gabon." Great Ape Societies. (1996): 58–70. Print.</ref> They are often found on the ground and are made up of up to 30 gorillas. Western lowland gorillas live in the smallest family groups of all gorillas, with an average of 4 to 8 members in each. The leader (the silverback) organizes group activities, like eating, nesting and travelling in their home range. Those who challenge this alpha male are apt to be cowed by impressive shows of physical power. He may stand upright, throw things, make aggressive charges, and pound his huge chest with open or cupped hands while barking out powerful hoots or unleashing a frightening roar. Despite these displays and the animals' obvious physical power, gorillas are generally calm and nonaggressive unless they are disturbed. Young gorillas, from three to six years old, remind human observers of children. Much of their day is spent in play, climbing trees, chasing one another and swinging from branches.<ref name="animals.nationalgeographic.com">{{cite web|url=http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/lowland-gorilla/|title=Western Lowland Gorilla|work=National Geographic|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref>
===Reproduction=== Female western lowland gorillas do not produce many offspring due to the fact that they do not reach sexual maturity until the age of 8 or 9.<ref name="Western Lowland Gorilla">{{cite web|url=http://www.wcs.org/saving-wildlife/great-apes/western-lowland-gorillas.aspx|title=Western Lowland Gorilla|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref> Female gorillas give birth to one infant after a gestation period of nearly nine months. Female gorillas do not show signs of pregnancy. Unlike their powerful parents, newborns are tiny—weighing four pounds—and able only to cling to their mothers' fur. These infants ride on their mothers' backs from the age of four months through the first two or three years of their lives.<ref name="animals.nationalgeographic.com" /> Infants can be dependent on their mother for up to five years.<ref name="Western Lowland Gorilla" />
A study of over 300 births to captive female gorillas revealed that older females tend to give birth to more male offspring as opposed to females under 8 years old. This pattern is likely to result from selective pressures on females to have males at a time when they can provision them most effectively, as male reproductive success probably varies more than that of females and depends more on the maternal role.<ref>{{cite journal|year=1990|title=Birth Sex Ratio and Infant Mortality Rates in Captive Western Lowland Gorillas|journal=Folia Primatologica|volume=55|issue=3–4|pages=156|doi=10.1159/000156511|author=Mace, G.M.}}</ref> [[File:ZOO Praha - Moja 03.jpg|thumb|right|A young western lowland gorilla at [[Prague Zoo|Praha Zoo]]]] Female western lowland gorillas living in a group led by a single male have been observed to display sexual behavior during all stages of their reproductive cycle and during times of non-fertility. Three out of four females have been observed to engaged in sexual behavior while pregnant and two out of three females have been observed to engage in sexual behavior while lactating. Females are significantly more likely to engage and participate in sexual behavior and activity on a day when another female is sexually active. It has been found that female western lowland gorillas participate in non-reproductive sexual behavior in order to increase her reproductive success through sexual competition. By increasing the female’s own reproductive success, she then decreases the reproductive success of others female gorillas, regardless of their reproductive state.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stoinski|first=Tara|date=July 2009|title=Sexual behavior in female western lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla''): evidence for sexual competition|journal=American Journal of Primatology|volume=71|issue=7|pages=587–593|doi=10.1002/ajp.20692|pmid=19399838|author2=Bonnie Perdue}}</ref>
Infanticide has occasionally been observed within the species. Infanticide is when an adult male gorilla kills an infant gorilla. Victims are never related to the killer. A male does this in order to have the opportunity to mate with the mother, who otherwise would have been unavailable while caring for her young offspring.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Stokes |first1=Emma J |last2=Parnell |first2=Richard J |last3=Olejniczak |first3=Claudia |title=Female dispersal and reproductive success in wild western lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') |journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology |date=1 September 2003 |volume=54 |issue=4 |pages=329–339 |doi=10.1007/s00265-003-0630-3}}</ref>
==Intelligence==
===Use of tools=== Their intelligence is displayed through their ability to fashion natural materials into tools that help them gather food more conveniently. While the use and manufacture of tools to extract ants and termites is a well-documented behavior in wild chimpanzees, it has never been observed in other great apes in their natural habitat and never seen to be done by other primates in captivity. [[File:Gorilla tool use.png|thumb|A female gorilla measuring depth of water with a branch at [[Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park]], northern [[Republic of the Congo]], an example of tool use]] In terms of manufacturing tools for the use of extracting for western lowland gorillas, gorillas are able to adapt tools to a particular use by selecting branches, removing projections such as leaves and bark and adapting their length to the depth of the holes. It appears that they also anticipate the use of the tool since they begin with biggest sticks available and progressively modify it until it is the perfect fit for inserting into a hole that contains food. This demonstrates the gorillas' acquisition of high level sensorimotor intelligence similar to that of young human children.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pouydebat|first=Emmanuelle|author2=Berge, Christine |author3=Gorce, Philippe |title=Use and Manufacture of Tools to Extract Food by Captive ''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'': Experimental Approach|journal=Folia Primatologica|year=2004|volume=76|issue=3|pages=180–183|doi=10.1159/000084381|last4=Coppens|first4=Yves}}</ref>
In the past, there was a gorilla that used a stick to measure the depth of water. In 2009, a western lowland gorilla at [[Buffalo Zoological Gardens]] used a bucket to collect water. In an experiment, one adult male gorilla and three adult female gorillas were given five-gallon buckets near a standing pool. Two of the younger females were able to fill the buckets with water. This is the first record of gorillas spontaneously using tools to drink in zoos.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Kleinfelder III|first1=Raymond E.|last2=Margulis|first2=Susan W.|last3=Steele|first3=Gary R.|title=Use of Buckets as Tools by Western Lowland Gorillas|doi=10.1002/zoo.21001|pmid=22290615|volume=31|journal=Zoo Biol|pages=260–6}}</ref>
===Communication=== Another example of gorillas' significant intelligence is their ability to comprehend simple sign language.<ref name="animals.nationalgeographic.com" /> In the mid-1970s, researchers turned their attention to communicating with gorillas via sign language. One gorilla, [[Koko (gorilla)|Koko]], was born in [[San Francisco Zoo]] on July 4, 1971. A woman named [[Francine Patterson]] officially started working with Koko on July 12, 1972, with the goal of teaching her sign language. In the beginning, Dr. Petterson focused on teaching Koko only three basic signs: "food", "drink", and "more". Koko would learn signs through observation, Dr. Patterson, or one of her colleagues by molding Koko's hands into the correct sign. On August 7, Patterson began a more formal routine of teaching Koko the signs, "food", "drink", and "more". In the couple weeks before that, Koko had been using gestures that seemed like attempts at the signs taught, but were deemed as coincidental and random and not intended for the actual purpose. Only two days after they started the more formal routine, Koko started responding consistently with the sign "food" when prompted to.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Education of Koko|last=Patterson|first=Francine|publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston|year=1981|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> Within the first three months, Koko made 16 different combinations of signs and was also starting to form simple questions by using eye contact and different positioning of signs by the body. Koko mastered more than 1,000 signs and was said to be able to connect up to 8 words together to form a statement expressing wants, needs, thoughts, or simple responses.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanly|first=Elizabeth|date=June 18, 2004|title=LISTENING TO KOKO|url=|journal=Commonweal|volume= 131| issue = 12|pages=pgs 14–17}}</ref> Koko passed away, in her sleep, at [[The Gorilla Foundation]] in Woodside, California on June 19, 2018 at the age of 46.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Elkin |first1=Elizabeth |last2=Ahmed |first2=Saeed |title=Koko, the gorilla who mastered sign language, has died |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/21/health/koko-gorilla-death-trnd/index.html |accessdate=2018-08-25 |work=CNN}}</ref>
There has been a study examining the ability of western lowland gorillas to give to and exchange with humans. This involved humans holding objects such as fruit, leaves or peanuts in one hand. Once the gorillas had given twigs to the humans, they would receive one of these objects. If the gorillas did not give them a twig, they would not get their desired object. The gorillas were shown to quickly learn about receiving rewards as mistakes made by the gorillas in the beginning of the experiments gradually decreased.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/BF02557563|title=Exchange of objects between humans and captive western lowland gorillas|journal=Primates|volume=39|issue=4|pages=389|year=1998|last1=Chalmeau|first1=Raphaël|last2=Peignot|first2=Patricia}}</ref>
Studies of the mental capacity of western lowland gorillas continue.
==Ecology==
===Habitat=== Western lowland gorillas primarily live in rain forests, swamp forest, brush, secondary vegetation, clearing and forest edges, abandoned farming fields and riverine forests. They live in primary and secondary lowland tropical forests that have elevations that extend from sea level up to 1,300 meters. The average amount of rainfall in the areas where western lowland gorillas typically reside is about 1,500 millimetres a year with the greatest rainfall between the months of August and November. Western lowland gorillas are not typically observed in areas that are close to human settlements and villages. They have been known to avoid areas with roads and farms that show signs of human activity. These gorillas favor areas where edible plants are more copious. Swamp forests are now considered important feeding areas and habitats for the western lowland gorilla. These areas support the gorillas in both the wet and the dry season of the forest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yog2009.org/index.php?view=article&catid=46%3Agorillaspecies&id=63%3Awlgspeciesinfo&option=com_content&Itemid=70|title=Western Lowland Gorillas|publisher=YoG|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914094937/http://www.yog2009.org/index.php?view=article&catid=46%3Agorillaspecies&id=63%3Awlgspeciesinfo&option=com_content&Itemid=70|archivedate=14 September 2011|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref> The forests of the Republic of Congo are currently considered to host the majority of the western lowland gorilla population. The forests of the Republic of Congo serve as protection to the gorillas with the isolation of the large swampy forest areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/endangered_species/great_apes/gorillas/western_lowland_gorilla/|title=Western lowland gorilla|publisher=WWF Global|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref>
===Diet=== As primarily herbivores, the main diet of western lowland gorilla groups is roots, shoots, fruit, wild celery, tree bark and pulp which is provided for in the thick forests of central and west Africa.<ref name="animals.nationalgeographic.com" /> During the wet season gorillas commonly consume fruits. While in the dry season, there is a decrease in the consumption of fleshy fruits, but they still continue to eat other kinds of fruits. The diversity of fruits consumed was higher in the poor fruit year,when favored fruit species, failed to produce large crops.<ref name="Remis1997"/> They may also eat insects from time to time. The common food item within fibers are the herbaceous stems.<ref name="Remis1997"/> Important food species have been divided into three categories. Staple foods which are eaten on a daily/weekly basis throughout the year, seasonal foods which are present in the majority of resources when available and fallback foods which are always available, but eaten only or mainly during fruit-scarce months.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rogers|first=M. Elizabeth|last2=Abernethy|first2=Kate|last3=Bermejo|first3=Magdalena|last4=Cipolletta|first4=Chloe|last5=Doran|first5=Diane|last6=Mcfarland|first6=Kelley|last7=Nishihara|first7=Tomoaki|last8=Remis|first8=Melissa|last9=Tutin|first9=Caroline E.G.|date=1 October 2004|title=Western gorilla diet: A synthesis from six sites|journal=American Journal of Primatology|volume=64|issue=2|pages=173–192|doi=10.1002/ajp.20071|pmid=15470742}}</ref> The adult will eat around {{Convert|18|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of food per day.<ref name="Lukas1999">{{Cite journal|year=1999|title=A review of nutritional and motivational factors contributing to the performance of regurgitation and reingestion in captive lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'')|journal=Applied Animal Behaviour Science|volume=63|issue=3|pages=237–249|doi=10.1016/S0168-1591(98)00239-1|pmc=|pmid=|last1=Lukas|first1=K. E.}}</ref> Gorillas will climb trees up to 15 meters in height in search of food. They never completely strip vegetation from a single area since the rapid regrowth of the vegetation allows them to stay within a reasonably confined home range for extended periods of time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/accounts/Gorilla_gorilla/#lifespan_longevity|title=Gorilla gorilla western gorilla|last=Csomos|first=Rebecca Ann|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref> The western lowland gorilla eats a combination of fruits and foliage, providing a balance of nutrients, depending on the time of year. However, when ripe fruit is available, they tend to eat more fruit as opposed to foliage. When ripe fruit is in scarce supply, they eat leaves, herbs and bark. During the rainy months of July and August, fruit is ripe; however, in the dry seasons, ripe fruit is scarce. Gorillas choose fruit that is high in sugar for energy, as well as fibre.<ref>{{cite journal|last2=Dierenfeld|first2=E. S.|last3=Mowry|first3=C. B.|last4=Carroll|first4=R. W.|year=2001|title=Nutritional Aspects of Western Lowland Gorilla (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') Diet During Seasons of Fruit Scarcity at Bai Hokou, Central African Republic|journal=International Journal of Primatology|volume=22|issue=5|pages=807|doi=10.1023/A:1012021617737|last1=Remis|first1=M. J.}}</ref>
==Relationship with humans== The presence of western lowland gorillas has allowed humans to further the study of how gorillas compare with humans in regards to human diseases, behavior, linguistic and psychological aspects of their lives. They are hunted illegally for their skins and meat in Africa and captured to be sold to zoos. While defended as being economically profitable for restaurants and local people, it is a large contributor to the endangered status of the western lowland gorilla. They are also seen as a crop pest in western Africa because they raid native plantations and therefore destroy what would have otherwise been valuable crops.<ref name="Csomos"/>
===Threats===
====Hunting and logging==== In tropical forests, gorillas are hunted to provide meat for the bushmeat trade. Logging also destroys gorilla habitats. Although logging diminishes gorilla habitats, it may also provide for increased herbaceous vegetation as a result of gaps in the tree cover. Destruction of gorilla habitat may harm the overall forest ecosystem. Western lowland gorillas are seed dispersers, which mean they carry seeds from one place to another, and this trait is beneficial to many of the animals in the forest. Therefore, if there are no western lowland gorillas to disperse the needed seeds to other animals, not only will the gorillas become extinct but so will many other animals, which could over time destroy an entire ecosystem.<ref name="impact">{{cite journal|last-author-amp=yes|year=2013|title=Impacts of logging and hunting on western lowland gorilla (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') populations and consequences for forest regeneration. A review|url=http://popups.ulg.ac.be/1780-4507/index.php?id=9965|journal=Biotechnologie, Agronomie, Société et Environnement|volume=17|issue=2|pages=364–372|author=Haurez, B.|author2=Petre, C.|author3=Doucet, J.}}</ref>
====Population decline and recovery==== [[File:Western Lowland Gorilla at Bronx Zoo 4.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Western lowland gorilla at Bronx Zoo|[[Bronx Zoo]]]] The western lowland gorilla population in the wild is faced by a number of factors that threaten its extinction. Such factors include deforestation, farming, grazing and the expanding human settlements that cause forest loss. There is a correlation between human intervention in the wild with the destruction of habitats and increase in bushmeat hunting.<ref name="animals.nationalgeographic.com" /> Another of these factors is infertility. Generally, female gorillas mature at 10–12 years of age (or earlier at 7–8 years) and their male counterparts mature more slowly, rarely strong and dominant enough to reproduce before 15–20 years of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seaworld.org/animal-info/info-books/gorilla/reproduction.htm|title=GORILLAS- Reproduction|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref> The [[fecundity]] of females, or capacity of producing young in great numbers, appears to decline by the age of 18. Of one half of captive females of viable reproductive age, approximately only 30% of those had only a single birth. However, these non-reproductive gorillas may prove to be a valuable resource since the use of assisted reproductive techniques aid in the maintaining of genetic diversity in the limited populations in zoos.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hatasaka|first=Harry H.|date=February 1997|title=Strategies for ovulation induction and oocyte retrieval in the lowland gorilla|journal=Journal of Assisted Reproduction and Genetics|volume=14|issue=2|pages=102–110|doi=10.1007/bf02765779|pmc=3454829|pmid=9048241|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===Conservation=== [[File:Flachlandgorilla mit Baby.JPG|thumb|right|Female western lowland gorilla with her baby, born at this day at [[Durrell Wildlife Park]]]] In the 1980s, a census of the gorilla populations in equatorial [[Africa]] was thought to be 100,000. Researchers later adjusted the figure to less than half because of poaching and diseases.<ref name="wcs">{{cite news|url=http://www.wcs.org/news-and-features-main/motherlode-of-gorillas-discovered-in-central-africa.aspx|title=Motherlode of Gorillas Discovered in Central Africa|date=5 August 2008|publisher=[[Wildlife Conservation Society]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65k99YIRS|archivedate=26 February 2012|deadurl=no|accessdate=26 February 2012}}</ref> Surveys conducted by the [[Wildlife Conservation Society]] in 2006 and 2007 found about 125,000 previously unreported gorillas have been living in the swamp forests of [[Lake Télé Community Reserve]] and in neighboring [[Marantaceae]] (dryland) forests in the Republic of the Congo. However, gorillas remain vulnerable to [[Ebola]], [[deforestation]] and [[poaching]].<ref name="wcs" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2008-08-05/world/congo.gorillas_1_gorillas-researchers-congolese?_s=PM:WORLD|title=More than 100,000 rare gorillas found in Congo|date=5 August 2008|publisher=CNN|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65k9ABWt7|archivedate=26 February 2012|deadurl=no|accessdate=26 February 2012}}</ref>
In 2002 and 2003, there was an Ebola outbreak in the Lossi sanctuary population, and in 2004, there was an Ebola outbreak in the Lokoué forest clearing in [[Odzala-Kokoua National Park]], both in the Republic of the Congo. The Ebola outbreak in the Lokoué forest clearing negatively affected the individuals living in groups and the adult females more than the solitary males, resulting in an increase in the proportion of solitary males to those living in groups. This population decreased from 377 individuals to 38 individuals two years after the outbreak and to 40 individuals six years after the outbreak. The population is still slowly recovering, even today, it is hoped towards a population that has the same demographic structure of an unaffected population, because of new births and breeding groups. This Ebola outbreak also affected the Maya Nord population (52 kilometres northwest from Lokoué) from 400 individuals to considerably fewer. Because of these outbreaks, the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) updated the status of western lowland gorillas from "endangered" to "critically endangered".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Genton|first=Céline|year=2012|title=Recovery Potential of a Western Lowland Gorilla Population following a Major Ebola Outbreak: Results from a Ten Year Study|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=7|issue=5|pages=e37106|bibcode=2012PLoSO...737106G|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0037106|pmc=3359368|pmid=22649511|author2=Cristescu, Romane|author3=Gatti, Sylvain|author4=Levréro, Florence|author5=Bigot, Elodie|author6=Caillaud, Damien|author7=Pierre, Jean-Sébastien|author8=Ménard, Nelly|author9=Hayward, Matt}}</ref>
In the northeastern part of the Republic of the Congo, even though poaching is illegal, western lowland gorillas are still being hunted for their bushmeat and the young for pets; five percent of the species is killed each year because of this. Deforestation of this area allows for the trade of bushmeat and even more poaching.<ref>[http://worldwildlife.org/species/western-lowland-gorilla "Western Lowland Gorilla."] World Wildlife Fund. Ed. Matthew Lewis and Richard Carroll. 2013.</ref> Commercial poaching of chimpanzees, forest elephants and western gorillas in The Republic of the Congo resulted from the increased amount of commercial logging and infrastructure. Deforestation and logging allowed for the creation of roads which allowed hunters to hunt deeper into the forests, increasing the amount of poaching and bushmeat trade in the area. The Republic of the Congo has put in place a conservation effort to conserve different species such as chimpanzees, forest elephants and western gorillas from poaching and deforestation. This conservation effort would allow these species to benefit from vegetation and ecologically important resources.<ref>{{cite journal|last3=Bakabana|first3=Parfait C.|last4=Elkan|first4=Paul W.|last5=Iyenguet|first5=Fortuné C.|last6=Madzoké|first6=Bola|last7=Malanda|first7=Guy Aimé F.|last8=Mowawa|first8=Brice S.|last9=Moukoumbou|first9=Calixte|year=2010|title=Monitoring Great Ape and Elephant Abundance at Large Spatial Scales: Measuring Effectiveness of a Conservation Landscape|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=5|issue=4|pages=e10294|bibcode=2010PLoSO...510294S|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0010294|pmc=2859051|pmid=20428233|author12=Getz, Wayne M.|last1=Stokes|first1=Emma J.|author2=Strindberg, Samantha|last10=Ouakabadio|first10=Franck K.|last11=Rainey|first11=Hugo J.}}</ref>
Bush meat hunting and timber harvesting in the western lowland gorilla’s habitat have negatively affected the probability of its survival. The western lowland gorilla is considered to be critically endangered by the IUCN. The western lowland gorillas, like many gorillas, are essential to the composition of the rainforest due to their seed distribution.<ref name="impact" /> The conservation of the Western Lowland gorilla has been made a priority by many organizations. The Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) has been working with the local community in the Congo Basin to establish wildlife management programs. The WCS is also working in Congo and surrounding countries to limit the bush meat trade by enforcing laws and hunting restrictions and also helping the local people find new sources of protein.<ref>[http://www.wcs.org/saving-wildlife/great-apes/western-lowland-gorillas.aspx "Western Lowland Gorilla."] – Saving Wildlife.</ref>
Zoos worldwide have a population of 550 western lowland gorillas, and the [[Cincinnati Zoo]] leads the United States in western lowland gorilla births.<ref name="Prince-Hughes66" />
==In captivity==
===Stress=== Stress has been known to cause both physiological and behavioral chronic issues for captive species including, but not limited to, altered reproductive cycling and behavior, reduced immune responses, disrupted hormone and growth levels, reduced body weight, heightened abnormal activities and aggression and decreased exploratory behavior with increased hiding behaviors.<ref name="Morgan2007">{{cite journal | last1 = Morgan | first1 = K | last2 = Tromborg | first2 = C | year = 2007 | title = Sources of stress in captivity | url = | journal = Applied Animal Behaviour Science | volume = 102 | issue = 3–4| pages = 262–302 | doi = 10.1016/j.applanim.2006.05.032}}</ref> Such stress reactions could be caused by sounds, light conditions, odors, temperature and humidity conditions, material make-up of enclosures, habitat size constraints, lack of proper hiding areas, forced closeness to humans, routine husbandry and feeding conditions, or abnormal social groups to name a few.<ref name="Morgan2007"/> Use of both internal and external privacy screens on exhibit windows has been shown to alleviate stresses from visual effects of high crowd densities, leading to decreased stereotypic behaviors in the gorillas.<ref name="Clark2011" /> Playing naturalistic auditory stimuli as opposed to classical music, rock music, or no auditory enrichment (which allows for crowd noise, machinery, etc. to be heard) has been noted to reduce stress behavior as well.<ref>Robbins L, Margulis S. The effects of auditory enrichment on gorillas. Zoo Biology. 2014 [accessed 2015 Oct 12];33(3):197–203.</ref> Enrichment modifications to feed and foraging, where clover-hay is added to an exhibit floor, decrease stereotypic activities while simultaneously increasing positive food-related behaviors.<ref name="Clark2011" />
===Stereotypic behaviors=== [[Stereotypy (non-human)|Stereotypic behaviors]] are abnormal or compulsive behaviors. In captive gorillas, such common aberrant behaviors include eating disorders—such as regurgitation, reingestion and [[coprophagy]]—self injurious or conspecific aggression, pacing, rocking, sucking of fingers or lip smacking, and overgrooming <ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wells | first1 = D.L. | year = 2005 | title = A note on the influence of visitors on the behaviour and welfare of zoo-housed gorillas | url = | journal = Applied Animal Behaviour Science | volume = 93 | issue = | pages = 13–17 | doi = 10.1016/j.applanim.2005.06.019}}</ref> Negative vigilance of visitor behaviors have been identified as starting, posturing and charging at visitors.<ref name="Clark2011">{{cite journal | last1 = Clark | first1 = F | last2 = Fitzpatrick | first2 = M | last3 = Hartley | first3 = A | last4 = King | first4 = A | last5 = Lee | first5 = T | last6 = Routh | first6 = A | last7 = Walker | first7 = S | last8 = George | first8 = K | year = 2011 | title = Relationship between behavior, adrenal activity, and environment in zoo-housed western lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') | url = | journal = Zoo Biology | volume = 31 | issue = 3| pages = 306–321 | doi = 10.1002/zoo.20396}}</ref> Groups of bachelor gorillas containing young silverbacks have significantly higher levels of aggression and wounding rates than mixed age and sex groups.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Leeds | first1 = A | last2 = Boyer | first2 = D | last3 = Ross | first3 = S | last4 = Lukas | first4 = K | year = 2015 | title = The effects of group type and young silverbacks on wounding rates in western lowland gorilla (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') groups in North American zoos | url = | journal = Zoo Biology | volume = 34 | issue = 4| pages = 296–304 | doi = 10.1002/zoo.21218}}</ref> <ref name="Stoinski2011">{{cite journal | last1 = Stoinski | first1 = T | last2 = Jaicks | first2 = H | last3 = Drayton | first3 = L | year = 2011 | title = Visitor Effects on the Behavior of Captive Western Lowland Gorillas: The Importance of Individual Differences in Examining Welfare | url = | journal = Zoo Biology | volume = 31 | issue = 5| pages = 586–599 | doi = 10.1002/zoo.20425}}</ref> It is common for non-human primates kept in captivity to exhibit behaviors deviating from the normal behavior observed of them in the wilderness. A particular abnormal behavior is hair-plucking, which occurs across many species of mammals and birds. Studies made on the topic show that of all the western lowland gorillas housed in the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) population, 15% of the surveyed population displayed hair-plucking behavior with 62% of all institutions housing a hair-plucker. Individual gorillas, particularly those of a more solitary nature, are more likely to self-pluck using their fingers and pick up this behavior if they were exposed to a group member that plucked their hair as a youngster and not yet mature gorilla.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Less |first=E. H. |last2=Kuhar |first2=C. W. |last3=Lukas |first3=K. E. |journal=Animal Welfare |doi=10.7120/09627286.22.2.175 |url=http://www.ufaw.org.uk/documents/LESS.pdf |title=Assessing the prevalence and characteristics of hair-plucking behavior in captive western lowland gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') |year=2013 |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=175–183}}</ref>
Recent research on captive gorilla welfare emphasizes a need to shift to individual assessments instead of a one size fits all group approach to understanding how welfare increases or decreases based on a variety of factors.<ref name="Stoinski2011"/> Individual characteristics such as age, sex, personality and individual histories are essential in understanding that stressors will affect each individual gorilla and their [[animal welfare|welfare]] differently.<ref name="Clark2011"/><ref name="Stoinski2011"/>
==Genetics== {{Infobox genome| taxId = 2156| ploidy = diploid| chromosomes = 23 pairs| size = 3,035.66 Mb| year = 2012}}The gorilla became the next-to-last great ape genus to have its genome sequenced. This was done in 2012.<ref name="Scally">{{cite journal|last=Scally|first=Aylwyn|last2=Dutheil|first2=Julien Y.|last3=Hillier|first3=Ladeana W.|last4=Jordan|first4=Gregory E.|last5=Goodhead|first5=Ian|last6=Herrero|first6=Javier|last7=Hobolth|first7=Asger|last8=Lappalainen|first8=Tuuli|last9=Mailund|first9=Thomas|date=8 March 2012|title=Insights into hominid evolution from the gorilla genome sequence|journal=Nature|volume=483|issue=7388|pages=169–175|bibcode=2012Natur.483..169S|doi=10.1038/nature10842|pmc=3303130|pmid=22398555|last10=Marques-Bonet|first10=Tomas|last11=McCarthy|first11=Shane|last12=Montgomery|first12=Stephen H.|last13=Schwalie|first13=Petra C.|last14=Tang|first14=Y. Amy|last15=Ward|first15=Michelle C.|last16=Xue|first16=Yali|last17=Yngvadottir|first17=Bryndis|last18=Alkan|first18=Can|last19=Andersen|first19=Lars N.|last20=Ayub|first20=Qasim|last21=Ball|first21=Edward V.|last22=Beal|first22=Kathryn|last23=Bradley|first23=Brenda J.|last24=Chen|first24=Yuan|last25=Clee|first25=Chris M.|last26=Fitzgerald|first26=Stephen|last27=Graves|first27=Tina A.|last28=Gu|first28=Yong|last29=Heath|first29=Paul|last30=Heger|first30=Andreas|display-authors=29}}</ref> This has given scientists further insight into the evolution and origin of humans. Despite the chimpanzees being the closest extant relatives of humans, 15% of the human genome was found to be more like that of the gorilla.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/07/us-gorilla-genome-sheds-new-light-human-idUSTRE8261VA20120307|title=Gorilla genome sheds new light on human evolution|date=7 March 2012|author=Kelland, Kate|agency=Reuters|accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref> In addition, 30% of the gorilla genome "is closer to human or chimpanzee than the latter are to each other; this is rarer around coding genes, indicating pervasive selection throughout great ape evolution, and has functional consequences in gene expression".<ref name=Scally/> Analysis of the gorilla genome has cast doubt on the idea that the rapid evolution of hearing genes gave rise to language in humans, as it also occurred in gorillas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/news/gorilla-joins-the-genome-club-1.10185|title=Gorilla joins the genome club|date=7 March 2012|publisher=Nature News|author=Smith, Kerri}}</ref>
Furthermore, in 2013, a study was conducted in order to better understand the genetic variation in gorillas by using reduced representation sequencing. This study consisted of a sample of 12 western lowland gorillas and two eastern lowland gorillas all in captivity. The study found that western lowland gorillas are more likely to be heterozygous than homozygous. Most pure (meaning they are not inbred) western lowland gorillas have a hom/het ratio that ranges from 0.5 to 0.7. Therefore, because of variation in these gorillas, it has been concluded that they display a moderate substructure within the western lowland population in general.
Finally, the study sought out to analyze the allele frequency spectrum (AFS) in western lowland gorillas. The reason why is that AFS knowledge can help give information regarding demographics and evolutionary processes. The AFS has determined that western lowland gorillas display a deficit of rare alleles.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tyler-Smith|first=Chris|last2=Yngvadottir|first2=Bryndis|last3=Xue|first3=Yali|last4=Ayub|first4=Qasim|last5=Durbin|first5=Richard|last6=Tyler-Smith|first6=Chris|date=June 2013|title=A Genome-Wide Survey of Genetic Variation in Gorillas Using Reduced Representation Sequencing|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=8|issue=6|pages=1–9|bibcode=2013PLoSO...865066S|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0065066|pmc=3672199|pmid=23750230|arxiv=1301.1729}}</ref>
==Disease== Western lowland gorillas are believed to be one of the [[zoonotic]] origins of [[HIV/AIDS]]. The SIV or [[Simian immunodeficiency virus]] that infects them is similar to a certain strain of HIV-1.<ref name="VanHeuv">{{cite journal|last2=Li|first2=Yingying|last3=Neel|first3=Cecile|last4=Bailes|first4=Elizabeth|last5=Keele|first5=Brandon F.|last6=Liu|first6=Weimin|last7=Loul|first7=Severin|last8=Butel|first8=Christelle|last9=Liegeois|first9=Florian|year=2006|title=Human immunodeficiency viruses: SIV infection in wild gorillas|journal=Nature|volume=444|issue=7116|page=164|bibcode=2006Natur.444..164V|doi=10.1038/444164a|pmid=17093443|last1=Van Heuverswyn|first1=Fran|last10=Bienvenue|first10=Yanga|last11=Ngolle|first11=Eitel Mpoudi|last12=Sharp|first12=Paul M.|last13=Shaw|first13=George M.|last14=Delaporte|first14=Eric|last15=Hahn|first15=Beatrice H.|last16=Peeters|first16=Martine}}</ref><ref name="Plantier">{{cite journal|last2=Leoz|first2=Marie|last3=Dickerson|first3=Jonathan E|last4=De Oliveira|first4=Fabienne|last5=Cordonnier|first5=François|last6=Lemée|first6=VéRonique|last7=Damond|first7=Florence|last8=Robertson|first8=David L|last9=Simon|first9=François|year=2009|title=A new human immunodeficiency virus derived from gorillas|journal=Nature Medicine|volume=15|issue=8|pages=871–72|doi=10.1038/nm.2016|pmid=19648927|last1=Plantier|first1=Jean-Christophe}}</ref><ref name="Sharp2001">{{cite journal|last2=Bailes|first2=E.|last3=Chaudhuri|first3=R. R.|last4=Rodenburg|first4=C. M.|last5=Santiago|first5=M. O.|last6=Hahn|first6=B. H.|year=2001|title=The origins of acquired immune deficiency syndrome viruses: where and when?|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|volume=356|issue=1410|pages=867–76|doi=10.1098/rstb.2001.0863|pmc=1088480|pmid=11405934|last1=Sharp|first1=P. M.}}</ref><ref name="Takebe2008">{{cite book|title=HIV-1: Molecular Biology and Pathogenesis|last2=Uenishi|first2=R|last3=Li|first3=X|year=2008|isbn=9780123736017|series=Advances in Pharmacology|volume=56|pages=1–25|chapter=Global Molecular Epidemiology of HIV: Understanding the Genesis of AIDS Pandemic|doi=10.1016/S1054-3589(07)56001-1|last1=Takebe|first1=Y}}</ref> The HIV-1 virus exhibits phylogeographic clustering, which is due to large rivers. This clustering allows us to pinpoint the probable geographic origins of two of the human virus clades. In the southern part of Cameroon, the populations of western lowland gorillas have had examinations of their feces. Out of 2,934 gorilla samples, 70 reacted with at least one HIV-1 antigen. These samples came from four field sites, all located in southern Cameroon.<ref name="origin">{{Cite journal|last=D'arc|first=Mirela|last2=Ayouba|first2=Ahidjo|last3=Esteban|first3=Amandine|last4=Learn|first4=Gerald H.|last5=Boué|first5=Vanina|last6=Liegeois|first6=Florian|last7=Etienne|first7=Lucie|last8=Tagg|first8=Nikki|last9=Leendertz|first9=Fabian H.|date=2015|title=Origin of the HIV-1 group O epidemic in western lowland gorillas|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=112|issue=11|pages=E1343–E1352|bibcode=2015PNAS..112E1343D|doi=10.1073/pnas.1502022112|pmc=4371950|pmid=25733890|url=http://www.documentation.ird.fr/hor/fdi:010064059}}</ref>
The origin of AIDS has been linked to a virus known to infect more than 40 species of nonhuman primates in Africa. HIV-1, is composed of four phylogenetic lineages, which at some point in time have independently gone through cross-species transmission of the SIV (simian immune-deficiency virus). The simian immunodeficiency virus infected various African primates such as apes, gorillas and chimpanzees.<ref name="origin" />
Disease has also been a factor in the survival of the western lowland gorilla. The Ebola epizootic in western and central Africa has caused more than 90% mortality rate in western lowland gorillas. From 2003–2004, two epizootics infected the western lowland gorilla, which caused two thirds of their population to disappear. The outbreak was monitored in the Republic of Congo by [[Magdalena Bermejo]] and other field-based primatologists, as it also spread to humans through contact with bushmeat.<ref>{{cite journal|date=2009|title=How Ebola Impacts Genetics of Western Lowland Gorilla Populations|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=4|issue=12|pages=e8375|bibcode=2009PLoSO...4.8375L|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0008375|pmc=2791222|pmid=20020045|author1=Le Gouar, Pascaline|author2=Vallet, Dominique|author3=David, Laetitia|author4=Bermejo, Magdalena|author5=Gatti, Sylvain}}</ref> The catastrophe led the World Conservation Union to designate the western lowland gorilla a critically endangered species. [[Malaria]] is also an issue that has been arising for the western lowland gorillas. Out of 51 faecal samples from habituated individuals, 25 were shown to have ''[[Plasmodium]]'' DNA. ''[[Laverania]]'', which is a subgenus of the parasitic [[protozoa]]n genus ''Plasmodium'', was found in these studies. Varying exposure to different ''[[Anopheles]]'' mosquitoes transmitting ''Plasmodium'' species is known to be the origin of malaria in western lowland gorillas.
Wild western lowland gorillas are known to consume the seeds of the [[Aframomum melegueta#Uses|"grains of paradise"]] plant, apparently conferring healthy cardiovascular conditions from their consumption — the occasionally poor cardiovascular health of lowland gorillas in zoos has been postulated to be due to the lack of availability of the ''[[Aframomum]]'' seeds in zoo gorillas' diets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asknature.org/strategy/23ec7287a4207c835d8bf162ff26afcb|title=Gorilla diet protects heart: grains of paradise|date=20 February 2012|publisher=Asknature.org|accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> Adult male gorillas are prone to [[cardiomyopathy]], a degenerative [[heart disease]].<ref name="Schulman">{{Cite journal|last=Schulman|first=F. Yvonne|date=1 March 1995|title=Fibrosing Cardiomyopathy in Captive Western Lowland Gorillas (''Gorilla gorilla gorilla'') in the United States: A Retrospective Study|journal=Journal of Zoo and Wildlife Medicine|volume=26|issue=1|pages=43–51|jstor=20095434|author2=Andrew Farb|author3=Renu Virmani|author4=Richard J. Montali}}</ref>
